text:
<@U02U0AS3J49> I have a couple of issues with your view:
1. Most software dependencies are not between people but between organizations. Depending on Chrome means depending on Google. I don't even know who at Google is currently in charge of Chrome.
2. Equating "interacting with people" and "depending on someone else's software" doesn't sound right. Dependency relations are very specific and highly asymmetric relations. I can despise dependencies and yet collaborate with others at a peer-to-peer level.
3. When you say that rejecting Python for its instability is a maladaptive trait, did you consider that I also have moral or legal obligations to others that may force me to take such an attitude? My software doesn't live in some abstract space, it is used for professional work inside a community that has high standards of rigor and transparency.

elements.text: I have a couple of issues with your view:
Most software dependencies are not between people but between organizations. Depending on Chrome means depending on Google. I don't even know who at Google is currently in charge of Chrome.

Equating "interacting with people" and "depending on someone else's software" doesn't sound right. Dependency relations are very specific and highly asymmetric relations. I can despise dependencies and yet collaborate with others at a peer-to-peer level.

When you say that rejecting Python for its instability is a maladaptive trait, did you consider that I also have moral or legal obligations to others that may force me to take such an attitude? My software doesn't live in some abstract space, it is used for professional work inside a community that has high standards of rigor and transparency.

text: Yeah, <@UJBAJNFLK>, good points all. There are certainly situations in which avoiding dependencies in the software sense is justified. But it was hopefully useful to make an extreme version of the argument to critique it as a half-formed idea. I appreciate the feedback.

elements.text: , good points all. There are certainly situations in which avoiding dependencies in the software sense is justified. But it was hopefully useful to make an extreme version of the argument to critique it as a half-formed idea. I appreciate the feedback.
